pros: London weighted salary, extra 20% on base pay. Flexible work from home/office days Office space in wework is nice

pros: Trained at KCH, worked as Staff Nurse and then moved to Paediatric Research nursing. Variety of specialty wards, friendly staff.
cons: If you are part time do not expect to be promoted, especially if you have health needs and dependents. Research Management only see potential in younger, full-time staff, who are not parents. This is why I resigned.

review_title: One of the “okay” hospitals in London
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in London, England
pros: Gained a lot of experience as it is one of the top trauma hospitals in London.
cons: A little bit disorganzied where I worked at.

review_title: Stop the nepotism and tick boxing
pros: Staff at ground level go above and beyond.
cons: Senior management full of nepotism. Freedom to Speak up, bold strategy only a tick box. I know of so many people who have tried to highlight poor management, only for it to swept under the carpet. They have followed the rules only to be blocked. If your face don’t fit- forget it. Family Members given jobs not qualified for. Jobs given to people just because they are friends. People are tired of speaking up and following the rules to lodge complaints for only nothing to be done.

pros: I learned so much in this hospital from all the diversity in patients and staff alike. Felt like a family there
cons: Under a lot of pressure so often chaotically busy

review_title: If you can handle burnout at all time go for it

review_title: No room for promotion or progression
job_title: Pediatric Research administrator in London, England
pros: My original colleagues were great.
cons:
Not very compassionate when it comes to Mental Health. 
No room for development, when another department took over due to the poor leadership and gave the old staff were pushed out and gave their own staff "friends" promotions, when other staff worked above their band to achieve results for the department.
 Was made to leave due to the lack of support.
To many expectations put upon someone with lack of resources and support. 
Care more about making money than staff wellbeing.

Saving lives. That’s why we are here
Love my fellow kind doctors
cons: Some of the consultants and registrars, the men, are completely vile and rude and disgusting and bullies and just plain nasty. They have zero people skills zero patience zero empathy. The nhs is a mess.

job_title: Research Data Coordinator in Camberwell, England
pros: The only pro is if this trials unit gets shut down.
cons: Hand on heart - the worst place I have ever worked. Management is awful with complaints of bullying and harassment being filed against them. They have a disgusting attitude with junior employees and overwork them to the bone with no praise or appreciation. Unprofessional operational research managers and senior trial coordinators who ridicule and humiliate their employees in the office. I am genuinely surprised this trials unit has not been audited or closed down yet. I am very concerned about the mental and physical welfare of my colleagues who remain in the department. Line managers are not trained or competent and biased towards those who they have close personal ties and connections with. Toxic work culture and very little opportunity for career development.

review_title: Not enough resources to hold people to account
job_title: Procurement Systems and Services Administrator in London, England
pros: Pleasant people to work with, the state of existing systems is gradually improving.  Regular social events among staff.  Relative flexibility about start and finish times, so long as hours/week is as contracted.
cons: Like all the NHS, this hospital is chronically and (I suspect) deliberately under-funded by the government.  This lack of resources has allowed an increasing lack of oversight from those at the top of the hierarchy to develop, such that individuals have insinuated themselves into the middle that don't necessarily have the skills and temperament to maintain such a position, but are somehow still in it.  Their incompetence has held up much needed improvements in systems and processes across the department I worked in.  Led to many interruptions and unnecessary queries from service users.

review_title: Understand what you are getting into if before you accept
job_title: Business Transformation Manager in London, England
pros: - Some amazing people in the organisation
cons:
- The organisation is shortsighted & political without the appetite, direction or prioirtiation to change 
- The systems are chronically undersupported/ not fit for purpose leading to very inefficient services - that can't run at scale
- Organisational structure is so unbalanced which  will limit and substantial change

job_title: Medical Records Assistant in Orpington, England
pros: Pleasant colleagues & managers, reasonable pay
cons:
Bureaucratic NHS culture is a frustrating one, the longer you work in it. 
If it was up to me, I'd privatise the NHS tomorrow, making it free only for low incomes.

pros: Great work colleagues, most of whom are very dedicated to their work and wish to provide the best service possible for their patients.
cons: Bureaucracy. Too many unattended appointments which waste money. Some clerical staff have been there too long and are jaded. Offices and behind the scenes (non-ward) facilities leave much to be desired.
